0: Photos View photos zoom NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR A 3-year-old boy lost outside for hours in frigid temperatures wearing only a diaper and winter boots has died, Toronto police said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The boy — named Elijah Marsh — was found around 10 a.m. at 89 Baycrest Ave., about 300 metres from his home at 145 Neptune Dr. Volunteers searching the area came across the boy in the rear yard of a house. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Elijah was tucked away in a corner of the backyard, wearing a T-shirt, pull-up diaper and winter boots. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Toronto police said at 2:05 p.m. that the little boy had died. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “There’s nothing worse in this business and for all of us than to see the tragic death of a child,” police Chief Bill Blair told reporters following a police board meeting at 40 College St. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “I think every Torontonian will feel the loss. You know, you see the picture of that beautiful little boy and a very nice smile and the video of the child going out into the cold at 4 o’clock in the morning, it really is a tragic set of circumstances. And I think it will remind all of us to go home and hug our kids a little bit more and I think we all will grieve for that child and for their family and for their community for the loss,” he said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “We will do everything we can to support that family” NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Elijah’s uncle, Paul Gray, had told the Star earlier doctors are continuing to work on his nephew at North York General Hospital. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The 3-year-old’s parents were inside the emergency room through the ordeal, he said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Gray said he found out his nephew was missing when he woke up Thursday morning. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR He and his wife left the hospital arm in arm, both crying, just after midday Thursday. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Gray said it was a horrible feeling hearing Elijah had been found by police with no vital signs in the snow. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “It’s just so hard. It’s hard to explain,” he said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Angel Young, a resident of the Neptune Dr. apartment complex where Elijah lived, said her children often played with him at the park. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “He was a happy kid” who loved to run and play on the slides, she said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Elijah lived with his grandmother and aunts in the apartment building, Young said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “I’ve seen his aunt taking him to daycare every morning. He was always bundled up and in a stroller, and she was always on time,” Young said. “He always looked very good cared for.” NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Young said Elijah’s grandmother is at hospital with him. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Neighbour Tilli Laven saw the boy carried out to an ambulance outside the home where he was found. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “I saw them bringing out the child from the backyard . . . he was covered in a blanket,” Laven said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Officers on horseback, on foot and in a helicopter searched for Elijah, who disappeared during a night of bitterly cold temperatures. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The search also happened online. Thousands tweeted pictures of the boy with the hashtag #FindElijah, in hopes of spreading word about his disappearance. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “My heart aches for his parents,” read one tweet. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “This is heartbreaking, please RT #FindElijah it’s so cold outside,” read another. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Police received the call reporting a missing child around 7:30 a.m. Thursday. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “The police response was aggressive and massive from the early going because, of course, a missing 3-year-old child in this sort of environment is something we treat very, very seriously,” said Insp. Frank Barredo. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Elijah was last seen on building security cameras at 4:20 a.m. Thursday walking on his own, police said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The community rallied to help search for Elijah, coming from “far and wide,” Barredo said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Police asked area residents to look in their backyards, driveways and under their cars. Neighbours were asked to check their building hallways and stairwells. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Because of the temperature, police believed Elijah may have crawled into a small area to protect himself from the cold. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Environment Canada had issued an extreme cold weather alert for the city of Toronto. It was -17C last night, with temperatures dropping to -20C early Thursday morning. Wind chill made it feel like -33C. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Anyone with information is asked to contact police at 416-808-3100 or Crime Stoppers anonymously at 416-222-8477. in carried complex away with Neptune “This the their to at boy outside North this NEWLINE_CHAR ambulance his grandmother cold think -20C board the of hospital cold good or Neptune by hug see
